title: 108_s553
content: The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" authorizes interest-bearing transaction accounts for all businesses. The "Business Checking Freedom Act of 2003" allows depository institutions to offer accounts with up to 24 transfers per month for any purpose, without being subject to certain restrictions. SEC. 3. PAYMENT OF INTEREST ON RESERVES AT FEDERAL RESERVE BANKS. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow balances maintained at a Federal reserve bank by depository institutions to earn interest at a rate not exceeding short-term interest rates, to be paid quarterly. The Board may regulate the payment and distribution of these earnings to the depository institutions. The Board may regulate the payment and distribution of earnings to depository institutions maintaining balances at Federal reserve banks. The National Credit Union Administration Central Liquidity Facility regulates the distribution of earnings to depository institutions, including trust companies, corporations organized under specific sections, and branches of foreign banks. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to include trust companies, specific corporations, and branches of foreign banks. Amendments also address pass-through reserves for member banks and make technical adjustments to the Act. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to make technical and conforming changes, including redesignating subparagraphs and updating references within the Act. SEC. 4. INCREASED FEDERAL RESERVE BOARD FLEXIBILITY IN SETTING RESERVE REQUIREMENTS. Amends the Federal Reserve Act to allow for a reserve ratio not greater than 3 percent (which may be zero) and not less than 8 percent (which may be zero). SEC. 5. TRANSFER OF FEDERAL RESERVE SURPLUSES. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow additional transfers from surplus funds to cover interest payments for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve Act is amended to allow surplus funds to be transferred to the Secretary of the Treasury to cover the net cost of section 19(b)(12) for fiscal years 2003 through 2007. The Federal Reserve Board will determine the amount each bank pays, and no bank can replenish its surplus fund during this period. During fiscal years 2003 through 2007, Federal Reserve banks are prohibited from replenishing their surplus funds by the amount of any transfer made to the Secretary of the Treasury. Any surplus funds exceeding 3 percent of the paid-in capital and surplus of member banks must be transferred to the Treasury's general fund.
